segments.text: This is a test.
This is an interview with Dr. Trevino, Doctor of Veterinary Medicine.
Today's date is June 12th, 1980.
This is Terry Anderson.
This is a test.
This is an interview with Dr.
Gerberto Trevino, Department of Veterinary Pathology, Texas A&M University, one of the series of the oral history project concerning the College of Veterinary Medicine.
Today is June 12, 1980, and this is Terry Anderson.
Could you tell us about your early life?
You were born in Laredo, or grew up in Laredo.
I was born in Laredo, and I was one of six boys born to my mother.
No girls.
My father was a rancher in South Texas.
So I acquired a love for animals at a very early age in my existence.
What type of ranch?
It was a 2,640 acres cattle ranch.
He also operated a dairy.
It was a Jersey dairy.
And so that's where I was born and reared, in this type of environment.
What type of cattle?
He had in his dairy only jerseys, and for beef he raised breamons.
Ultimately crossing these, because the jerseys were very good milkers and they were able to wean some pretty heavy calves.
As a matter of fact, we still own, my brother and I own 640 acres in Webb County.
And I try to go back there maybe twice a year or so.
But that's the background.
What happened to the rest of the ranch?
Well, we sold 2,000 acres in 1947.
I went to school in Laredo.
And I graduated from Martin High School there.
That was the only high school in Laredo at that time.
When was that?
When did you graduate?
I graduated in 1942.
And in September of that year, I entered A&M.
And it was my intent to be a chemical engineer.
Why did you come to A&M?
Why did you choose A&M?
Well, I chose A&M, I suppose it was at the urging of one of my high school teachers who was very influential in my life.
He was a chemistry teacher, and he thought that I would do very well in chemical engineering, but that wasn't my bag.
I stayed here.
Was that one of your good fields in high school?
Oh, yeah.
I did very well in chemistry in high school and physics and math.
And then I attended A&M from September 1942 until the Marines called me.
And I entered the Marines in May of 1944.
So you were drafted then?
I was drafted.
Could you describe the campus during the Second World War?
Well, you see, when I came here in 1942, we had a total of enrollment, enrollment of around
I can't tell you with any degree of precision about this.
No, no, that's about right.
It's about 6,500.
And of course, we were all boys.
And all the freshmen were assigned to specific ROTC units.
And I was assigned to be chemical warfare.
And each one of these units occupied specifically designated dorms.
And I lived in dorm three for a long time.

And then at that time on this campus there was a lot of activity on the part of the military because they had a lot of people here who were involved in what they called at that time the Army Specialized Training Program, ASTP.
And these people were college graduates who were inducted as privates and who were attending courses here on this campus.
Some of them were about to receive their degrees.
Not all of them had completed their degrees.
Some of them, I suppose they were in their final year or the final two years.
Yeah, I think I would like to revise a little bit what I told you.
If I remember correctly, these ASTP boys were picked for their senior ROTC and inducted into the service.
Some of them into the Air Force, some of them into the Army.
It was sort of an officer's training school?
Yes, they were being trained
in their final undergraduate years by the service with the stipulation that upon completion of their degree requirements, they would enter the service and pay back some of this time, see.
That was the deal.
We had on this campus the Air Force candidates and Army, but I don't recall having seen any Navy
B-12 program people here.
At any rate, when those people went on to complete their degree requirements, they were simply picked up and they were compelled to serve for some time.
That was the intent, you see.
But then, as you know, the war ended in 1945 and a lot of those people
were just released without having to pay back any of this time, only to be recalled at some later date, like the Korean emergency.
So in those days now, we had a very strict discipline here on this campus.
The upperclassmen was king, as you know, the senior.
We still had a lot of hazing.
For example, what kind of hazing?
Well, I mean, the type of hazing we had was in the strictest traditions of A&M at that time.
That is to say, the freshmen wore a fish stripe on the cuff of their sleeve, on their shirt sleeve, and they were not permitted to use the sidewalks.
We had to function
as room orderlies for the upperclassmen, bring their mail, clean their room, make out their laundry, take it to the laundry, bring it back.
During mealtimes, we were compelled to give them what they called meal service, and you as a freshman could not partake of any food, you see, until every upperclassman at your table had been served.
And those things, besides the board beatings, we got a heck of a lot of board beatings, you know.
They used to break out a board and any upperclassmen who outranked another one could order a butt tear, see.
They'd line them up and whip everybody with a board.
That was traditional and it was very common.

we uh we used to to march to each meal there was no one at A&M here who was not in uniform those people that attended A&M and were unable to qualify for a commission because of some physical disability wore on their collars here an NM which meant non-military
You see?
But they still lived in the military dorm.
No kidding.
Yes, sir.
Now the student population of A&M went down from about 6,500 to about, I think it was about 2,500 during the war, basically because young men were being drafted.
Yes.
Also, I didn't know that it had reached that lower figure, but
A lot of, a lot of officers were being produced here at this university.
And this university produced more officers than any other service academy in the United States and any other military school.
As a matter of fact, as you well know, the commanding general of Corregidor was an Aggie, General George Moore.
Now were you happy to be drafted or did you want to continue?
No, I wanted to finish my undergraduate work, but unfortunately the war was not looking too good in those days.
They deployed a lot of young men, and in those days when I was called for active duty, I was given the choice of serving in the Navy or the Marines.
And I chose the Marines.
Why?
Well, I chose Marines for many reasons.

I was attracted to the Marines because of the stringent discipline that they exercised and because I knew that the Marine divisions were deployed in the Pacific, and I felt that if I volunteered for the Navy,
I don't like cold climates, and I didn't know where I would serve, so I knew that if I joined the Marines I would always remain in a tropical or subtropical climate.
And because of the fact that I thought that my military training at A&M, of which I had had two years, might give me a chance to go to the Marine Officer's Candidate School.
And did it?
No.
I was a private in the Marines, and after 17 months I was promoted to PFC.
I served in the Marines about two years.
Got out in 1946.
Where were you stationed?
I was stationed on Guam.
Well, I got my boot training in San Diego, California.
Then they sent me to Guam, where the 3rd Marine Division was based.
the 3rd Marine Division had already participated in two operations in Bougainville and in Guam.
So when we arrived there in December 1944, they were just cleaning up.
The Japanese stragglers still remained on the island.
And from that base on Guam, we participated in the invasion of Iwo Jima, which was
the hardest battle that the Marine Corps had ever fought in its history.
And you were in that battle?
I participated as a member of the 9th Marine Regiment, and I was in the 1st Battalion, Charlie Company.
We landed on that island on the 19th of February, 1945,

and after a very, very severe battle in which many Aggies died, some of whose names are on the list outside of the Memorial Student Center, we then secured the island on the 6th of April, and then we returned to Guam.
And then the war ended that year, 1945.
Were you in infantry then?
Yes, I was a machine gunner.
Oh, really?
Then I was assigned, believe it or not, to the Marine Corps headquarters in Washington, D.C. And then... After Guam?
After Guam.
And in February of 1946, I was released from the Marines.
My father at that time was dying of cancer, and he subsequently died in November of that year.
And then in June of 47, I returned to A&M as a student, this time as a pre-veterinary medical student.
I was accepted into the College of Veterinary Medicine.
I received my degree here in 1952.
Okay, now let's go back a minute here.
When you came in 1942, what was your course of study?
Engineering?
Chemical engineering, yeah.
And then why and when did you change?
When I was in Guam, my father bought a 2,000 acre ranch that I joined ours.
and uh he had so many cattle that it caused me to reconsider and I wrote a letter to Mr. H.L.
Heaton who was registrar here from Guam and I told him that I wanted to change my major from C.H.E.
chemical engineering to veterinary medicine and he wrote me a nice letter and told me I would have to go through a
selection process and to take a lot of pre-vet courses and all that.
So it was then established by 1940, 46, 47 that I would pursue a career in veterinary medicine or at least in pre-veterinary medicine.
And, of course, I didn't know that I was going to be selected the first time.
I was working towards an agricultural education degree as a contingency in the event I were rejected by the College of Animal Medicine.
And then you go out and teach?
Agricultural education.
But I was very lucky to have been accepted the first time.
Now, can you tell me about the acceptance process?
Well, at that time, we had a committee.
Did you have interviews?
Yeah, we had interviews.
Everybody was interviewed.
And uh...
I remember some of the people on my committee.
That is to say, on the selection committee.
Dr. Jaggi, Dr. Burns, Dr. Sam Cruz, and uh...

I believe it was those were three of my selection committee members in 1948 and uh the the questions that they ask you your selection was based on not only on your grades but also on the on the interview well they asked me for example one of the questions that I remember they're asking me is

if you were selected for admission to the College of Veterinary Medicine would you choose to be a large animal practitioner or a small animal practitioner and I think that that same question is being asked today in some form or another I don't know that but some of the students that have been before the committee have told me
My answer to that question was that I didn't know enough about veterinary medicine to make a choice before I was even admitted into the College of Veterinary Medicine.
And that I would defer my choice until I was in the third year of my professional work.
By that time I felt that I should have enough information that would steer me one way or another.
And they accepted that answer and they liked my, my, my candor
And I was selected.
In my class there were a lot of veterans.
I would think so.
Very highly intelligent people.
And I was very fortunate to be accepted because I was in with a lot of people who who had demonstrated academic ability.
Now, did you eventually get your bachelor's degree?
No.
No, I came very close to getting a bachelor's degree in ag education.
The only thing that I lacked in order to complete my requirements for a degree in ag ed were practice teaching.
Oh, really?
Yeah, I took many, many courses in ag ed.
I enjoyed it very much.
I've always enjoyed working around county agents
and agricultural people, you know, having been born and reared in a rural area.
And after I got out of here, in 1952, I wrote five letters applying for five different jobs, and I was accepted by all five.
Where were they?
What type of jobs?
Well, they were all small animals, small animals.
I was accepted by one of the outstanding practitioners in Miami, Florida, a fellow by the name of Charlie Bild, B-I-L-D.
He was... he was a very highly respected small animal practitioner, and
and also by a man in Louisiana who was an A&M graduate, and then also a doctor who signed my license there, Dr. Childress.
He was practicing here in Texas, and he accepted me, but the one that I was attracted to the most was California, and I practiced in Hollywood, California immediately after I got out of A&M.
and I had a lot of movie stars as my clients.

I went, I went in to work for an established older practitioner who had two veterinary hospitals and one of them was right across the street from the Republic Studios on Ventura Boulevard and that's where, that's where I went.
I was very happy there.
Let's, let's go back to

Now, I looked at the list of commencement ceremonies from 1920, and the first Mexican-American I found was a Ralph Gomez from Bryan, who graduated in 1936, and now it seems like he's in Tulsa, Oklahoma.
And by the time you graduated in 1952, it seems like you were only about the fifth or sixth Mexican-American who graduated

here now we did have some Cubans and we had some Puerto Ricans that graduated here and so I was wondering uh why we have so few to begin with no I I'm gonna have to disagree with you there because there were a lot many more Mexican Americans than that number that you quoted and I'm going to tell you why I know that okay because you see we used to have the Laredo A&M club and the Laredo A&M club was made up
were composed of Mexican-American students primarily.
But I'm talking about vet school.
Oh, in the vet school?
In the vet school.
I'm not talking about A&M.
Oh, you're probably right there, as a matter of fact.
I'm just talking about I know only one other.
I'm just talking about people who graduated with a doctorate.
I'm not talking about The only other Mexican-American that I know
that is finished from here, well, I'll bet that even today you won't find half a dozen.
Why?
Well, that's a tough question to answer.
First of all, this fellow Gomez, when did he finish?
And I know that there was another man by the name of Martinez from Heavenville.
I knew him personally.
Oh, did you know him?
Yeah, he was the second one that I found in 1937.
Yeah, that's right.
That's exactly right.
He was, as a matter of fact, I called him several times for veterinary assistance when I was operating my father's dairy.
Yeah.
That guy's a judge now, a county judge.
Is he a county judge?
Yes, sir.
Now, I personally taught a Mexican-American here by the name of Garza.
His name was Gilberto Garza.
He finished here in 1958.
Oh, okay.
Well, I only went up to you.
I only went up to 1952.
I didn't continue on.
But why do you, let's get back to that question.
Why do you think there's been so few

Well I don't know how to answer that question I know that there have been a lot of Mexican-Americans interested in veterinary medicine but I suppose the reason the most obvious reason is that that maybe their grades haven't been good enough to entitle them to an interview which is basal

it's primal to to the selection of a student for the professional curriculum is that he that a grade point average be so high that he merits an interview there's been a lot of people here from Laredo that have tried to be veterinarians they come across the same obstacles that any other kid comes across I think I really believe that the only way that we would have a higher uh proportion of Mexican-Americans
entering the College of Veterinary Medicine is if they were recruited at the high school level and interested in veterinary medicine.
And we don't have a program like that, do we?
To my knowledge, no.
To my knowledge, there isn't.
I believe that we would also have

a higher percentage of blacks that might be interested in veterinary medicine, but to my knowledge this university doesn't have an active recruitment program for minorities, and I think that they should.
I think that when people tell me, well, the reason why Mexican-Americans don't choose veterinary medicine as a career is that they know they're not intellectually qualified, and I consider that
to be bullshit.
I myself was in the top ten percent of my class here.
And when I went to get a Ph.D., I finished number one in my class at Michigan State.
It's not that they don't possess a mental aptitude.
It's just that they feel that the career is very long and maybe they come from lower income families and maybe
they feel that they ought to select a career that will enable them to get a job in four years.
I don't know what the reasons are.
There's probably a multiplicity of reasons.
Yes, yes.
Did you feel when you came here, first as an undergraduate, and then as one student of the vet school, did you feel that you were discriminated against in any way?
Dr. Anderson, that business of discrimination on this campus is rampant.
It is today rampant, and in those days it was worse.
Can you give me some examples?
Oh, there's, there's so many, you know, there's so many subtle ways in which discrimination can be practiced.
It is, it is quite difficult sometimes to, to identify specifically the reason for the discrimination or the instances of discrimination.
I feel that, well,
You tell me a single Mexican-American on this university campus that has any positional responsibility.
Name me one.
I can't.
I'm not an expert.
This state is composed of 30% Mexican-Americans.
We don't have anybody here that's a Mexican-American in positional responsibility.
American in Hernandez, I think his name was.
Danny Hernandez.
I think that's his name.
But he's supposed to be equal employment officer or something like that.
But aside from that,
I have gone through the faculty roster, to find out how many people here are teaching at A&M that have a Spanish surname.
Now, just a short time ago, the office of the vice president for academic affairs claimed that there were 140 minority people.
teaching here on this university campus.
A hundred and forty?
Yeah, but I've gone through that book there, and I can only find about five or six with a Spanish surname.
Oh, uh... Well, could you give me some examples when you were here back in the, back in the 40s, and then when you got here?
Of discrimination?
No.
Well, I guess one of the outstanding examples was
a fellow who was in my dorm.
He was classified as a junior.
He's now, he became a veterinarian, you know.
That's ironic, you know.
It really is ironic.
But in those days we were, you know, teenagers.
And this guy really had it in for Mexicans.
He said he had killed several of them on his father's ranch.
That's what he told me.
He couldn't tolerate them around him.
That fellow then went on to become veterinarian, and the irony of this thing is that I became a member of the teaching staff here, and we met at professional conventions.
As a matter of fact, there was one guy in my class
who never spoke to me for four years, that we went together every day to the same classes.
Is this in vet school?
In vet school.
The first one was in 1943 or 44.
That was the first example.
And this example is in vet school.
In vet school, yeah.
He never spoke to me.

when we were see he he joined our class from the class that was supposed to finish ahead of ours he failed of course and therefore was uh was put back a year you know and he joined our class now this guy I don't know he he had it in for Mexican Americans and of course I never made any effort to
cultivate his friendship and we went like that for four years he never spoke to me during four years we were here except in the final month when our graduation was a certainty then he
